resources.string: Avoid Scam\nKnow the scenario of International\nStudent in Australia
Trend of incoming international\nstudents in Australia

Check out our international student diversity snapshot for 2022! üåç üéì
 
 * China leads the pack, with a whopping 58.51% of our students hailing from there.
 * India isn't far behind, making up 26.22% of our vibrant community. 
 * The USA contributes 1.34% to our diverse community. 
 * Additionally, students from South Korea, Malaysia, Nepal, Brazil, Japan, Thailand, and Indonesia enrich our campus life.

Welcome to our Visa Arrivals Timeline! Take a peek at how visa arrivals to Australia have changed over the months and years. It's like flipping through a travel diary!
 
 * January 2019: 90,260 visa arrivals
 * January 2024: Strong at 82,890
 * February: Continuously increasing
 * March and April: Unpredictable
 * July 2023: Peak month with 131,640 arrivals
 
 Each month tells a unique story, reflecting the dynamic nature of travel trends. Join us on this fascinating journey through time !üõ´

Ever wondered how scammers are reaching out to their victims? Our bar chart below reveals exposure rates to different scam modes over the past two years. It's like peeking behind the curtain of cybercrime!
 
 * Over the Phone: Exposure spiked from 38.3% to 48.2% in just a year. Scammers are dialing up their game! 
 * Text Message: Scam exposure via SMS jumped from 23.4% to a whopping 46.5% in one year. 
 * Email: Although exposure rates dipped slightly from 32.2% to 37.1%, scammers are still lurking in your inbox.

Curious about where people report scams to seek help? Our chart below lays out the channels through which scam reports are made to various authorities over the past three years. It's like having a roadmap to report scams and protect yourself and others!
 
 * Bank or Financial Institution: Reports have steadily risen from 27.30% to 48.90% over three years. Alert your bank if you suspect fraudulent activity! 
 * Social Media or Selling Site: Reports have seen slight fluctuations, hovering around 8.70% to 11.10%. Stay vigilant online! 
 * Government Organization or Department: Some variation observed but remained stable, ranging from 8.40% to 11.80%. Don't hesitate to seek assistance! 
 * Police: Reports have notably increased from 8.20% to 13.90%. Law enforcement is here to help! 
 * Other: Reports to other authorities have remained consistent, ranging from 8.90% to 9.90%. 
 
 It's encouraging to see more people reporting scams, with overall reports to any authority increasing from 49.50% to 69.40%. By reporting scams, we empower ourselves and others to combat fraud effectively.

"\"What is the purpose of the pie chart?\" \n\n* \"The pie chart represents proportions of a whole by dividing a circular area into slices, with each slice's size proportional to the quantity it represents, making it easy to visualize the distribution or composition of data categories.\" "

"\"What information does the line chart convey?\" \n\n* \"The line chart illustrates trends and patterns over time or continuous data points by connecting them with straight lines, providing insights into changes and fluctuations.\" "
"\"What does the bar chart represent?\" \n\n* \"The bar chart visually displays categorical data using rectangular bars, where the length of each bar corresponds to the value it represents.\" "
\"What does the bar chart represent?\" \n\n* \"The bar chart visually displays categorical data using rectangular bars, where the length of each bar corresponds to the value it represents.\"
Do you really want to delete this history item?
If you have been scammed,\nconsider the following.
Reporting scams aids the victims and\nenables anti scam agencies to track\nscams and warn others
So, report scam immediately if you\nfeel you have been scammed

* Call 000 if your life is in danger and report your
local or territory police on 13 11 14
 
 * In case of an email, online or telephone scam
report to Scamwatch through the following link:
https://portal.scamwatch.gov.au/report-a-scam/
 
 * In case of financial scam report to Australian
Securities and Investment Commission on the
following link:
 https://moneysmart.gov.au/check-and-report-
 scams/report-an-investment-scam
 
 * For anonymous reporting call Crime Stoppers
over 1800 333 000
A victim of scam should consider\nthe following measures
Block all contacts from the scammer
Block all debit and credit cards
Warn family and friends about the scam
During a scam disaster follow the updates

"Blocking contact will prevent 
scammers from further 
communication and reduce 
risks "

How to block

	*Use your phone‚Äôs built-in Call blocking features
	*Add numbers to block list
	*You can also use third-party call blocking Apps
	*Use carrier call blocking services
	*Report scam numbers
	*Be cautious with unknown numbers

Register your numbers with ‚Äúdo not call‚Äù service of Australian government to stop unsolicited calls.

	https://www.donotcall.gov.au/consumers/register-your-numbers/
Block debit and credit cards\nimmediately for safeguarding\nyour financial accounts

*If you suspect your debit or credit card/s has been compromised, temporarily block them using the bank‚Äôs App.

*Contact with your bank through its scam reporting hotline 24/7. 

*Here are some of the major Australian banks‚Äô scam reporting hot-lines (24/7):
 
 NAB: 132265
 ANZ Bank: 132273
 CommBank: 132221

*Apply for new cards online via the App or in person at a nearby outlet.
Changing passwords of all\naccounts after a suspicious\nscam attack is crucial

Create strong and unique password based on the following guidelines:


	*Blending uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.
	*Making passwords 8‚Äì16 characters long.
	*Avoiding easy-to-guess patterns.
	*Using different passwords for each account.
	*Ensuring multi-factor authentication.
	*Regularly update passwords.
Alert family and friends to\nprevent them from falling\nvictim of the same scammers

Encourage family and friends to:

	*ignore unsolicited phone calls or emails asking for personal/financial information 
	*avoid urgent money or threats
	*report any suspicious activity with your family to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), Scamwatch or the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)
	*share the scam information with other family members
IDCARE helps scam victims in\nAustralia to make a plan (for\nfree) to limit further risks.

Contact IDCARE:

	Australia: 1800 595 160‚Äç
	QLD: 07 3555 5900
	ACT & NSW: 02 8999 3356
	VIC: 03 7018 2366
	NT, SA & WA¬†: 08 7078 7741

Business hours:
‚Ä® Mon - Fri: 8am - 5pm AEST

Report phishing:

	Email:¬†reportphishing@idcare.org

*Examine emergency alerts and notifications directly from relevant authorities

 *Follow official sources like government, law enforcement or reputable news agencies for updates during a scam disaster 

*Join in different discussion forums where users exchange information, support each other, and stay informed collectively

*Use your uni support service to prevent or get relief from scam attack
Legal support for scam victim\nis not free in Australia

*It is suggested that civil remedy is better than police or anti-scam agencies‚Äô intervention for a scam.

*So act quickly and follow the remedial actions to prevent scam
To begin type or paste\nyour message here...
You are right ‚Äì This is not a scam!
Oops, you‚Äôre wrong ‚Äì this is not a scam!
Awareness: By understanding the prevalent scam categories and their associated losses, you can better recognize and avoid potential scams, protecting yourself from financial harm
Embark on an enlightening journey through our area chart, where insights await those who seek a deeper understanding of financial dynamics.
Embark on a journey of analysis with our grouped bar chart, unraveling the intricate relationship between contact modes, financial losses, and report generation.

Understanding Scam Categories and Losses: 
 
 This graph visualizes different types of scams and the financial losses associated with each category. Each bar represents a scam category, and the height of the bar indicates the financial loss in millions of dollars. The text above each bar specifies the exact amount of loss. 
 
 
 Interpreting the Graph: 
 
 * Categories: Each category corresponds to a specific type of scam, such as investment scams, phishing, or online shopping scams. 
 
 * Losses: The height of each bar reflects the financial impact of scams in that category. Higher bars indicate greater financial losses.

Description: 

 Dive into our insightful area chart, illuminating the financial trajectory of 2022 and 2023. Explore monthly losses (in millions) alongside the consequential percentage change from 2022 to 2023.



 Key Insights: 

 üìà Trend Analysis: 

 Navigate the ebb and flow of losses month by month, uncovering essential financial performance trends. 



üîÑ Year-on-Year Comparison: 

 Engage in a thorough examination of losses between 2022 and 2023, deciphering the nuanced shifts in performance over time. 



üíº Percentage Change: 

 Delve into the quantitative realm, analyzing the substantial increases or decreases in losses from one year to the next. 




Interpretation Guide: 



üìä Upward Sloping Area: 

 Ascend to heightened awareness as you observe months with increased losses compared to the previous year, signaling areas of potential financial concern. 



üìâ Downward Sloping Area: 

 Descend into analysis as you encounter months with decreased losses compared to the previous year, unveiling promising signs of financial improvement. 



üõ§Ô∏è Flat Area: 

 Traverse through periods of stability, where minimal change in losses between the two years offers a serene interlude amidst the financial landscape.

Description: 

 Welcome to our informative grouped bar chart showcasing the interaction mode preferences and associated losses across two pivotal years: 2022 and 2023.



 Key Insights: 

 üìä Losses Analysis: 

 * Compare the financial impact of different contact modes in 2022 and 2023, represented by the height of the bars. 
 * Gain insights into changes in losses across various contact modes over the two years. 



üìà Reports Analysis: 

 * Explore the volume of reports generated through each contact mode in 2022 and 2023, depicted by the width of the bars. 
 * Understand the distribution of communication channels based on report generation.




 Interpretation Guide: 



üîç Losses Interpretation: 

 * Higher bars indicate greater financial losses associated with a specific contact mode. 
 * Compare the heights of bars within each year to assess changes in losses across different modes of contact. 



üìä Reports Interpretation: 

 * Wider bars represent a higher volume of reports generated through a particular contact mode. 
 * Analyze the width of bars within each year to understand trends in report generation across contact modes.




 Usage Tips: 


 üî¢ Interactive Features: 

 * Zoom in or out to focus on specific contact modes or years for detailed analysis. 



üîÑ Year Comparison: 

 * Observe changes in losses and report volumes between 2022 and 2023 to identify evolving communication patterns.
Our explanation of scam prevention capacity

7 Excellent
You beat the scammers, but don't forget to keep your wits about you.

5-3 Well done¬†‚Ä®‚Ä®
You‚Äôre pretty good at spotting a scam. Just don't let your guard down.
